title: DNA Synthesis — Writing the Code of Life
learningObjectives: Trace the history of DNA synthesis from the first dinucleotide in 1955 through modern chip-based platforms
Describe each step of the phosphoramidite synthesis cycle and explain why coupling efficiency limits oligo length
Compare column-based and chip-based synthesis in terms of throughput, cost, and applications
Explain how Gibson Assembly and Golden Gate Assembly join short oligos into full genes and pathways
Evaluate error correction strategies including MutS mismatch binding, dial-out PCR, and NGS verification
Discuss emerging synthesis technologies including enzymatic TdT-based synthesis and DNA data storage

sections.title: Introduction: The Art of Writing DNA
sections.content:
For most of the history of molecular biology, scientists were readers. They could extract DNA from organisms, sequence it, and marvel at the instructions encoded within. But a profound shift has taken place over the past several decades: we have learned to write DNA from scratch, nucleotide by nucleotide, constructing sequences that may never have existed in nature. This capability transforms biology from a purely observational science into an engineering discipline, one where we can design, build, and test genetic programs with increasing precision and ambition.

The story of DNA synthesis begins in 1955, when Alexander Todd and his student Michelson achieved what seemed at the time a modest feat: the chemical joining of two nucleotides into a dinucleotide. That single phosphodiester bond, forged in a flask rather than by an enzyme, represented something revolutionary. It demonstrated that the chemistry of life could be replicated, and eventually improved upon, by human hands. Within a decade, Har Gobind Khorana had extended this approach to synthesize defined oligonucleotides and even complete codons, work that would earn him a share of the 1968 Nobel Prize for deciphering the genetic code.

Fast forward to today, and the scale of DNA synthesis has expanded by many orders of magnitude. Companies like Twist Bioscience manufacture silicon chips containing over one million distinct oligonucleotides, each synthesized in a miniaturized well smaller than the width of a human hair. The cost of synthesizing a base pair of DNA has plummeted from roughly $1,000 in the early days of gene synthesis to well under a cent today, a cost reduction that mirrors and in some ways exceeds the trajectory of Moore's Law in semiconductors. Entire genomes have been written from scratch: the bacteriophage phiX174 in 2003, the complete Mycoplasma mycoides genome (over one million base pairs) by the J. Craig Venter Institute in 2010.

Joseph Jacobson, in his HTGAA lecture on DNA synthesis, framed the significance of this capability in a striking way. He described cells as programmable factories whose instruction sets—their genomes—we can now author from first principles. If sequencing is reading the book of life and CRISPR editing is correcting typos, then DNA synthesis is writing entirely new chapters, or even new books. This is the foundational technology of synthetic biology: the ability to specify an arbitrary DNA sequence and have it manufactured, at scale, at declining cost, and with ever-improving accuracy.

Emily Leproust, the CEO of Twist Bioscience and a guest lecturer in the HTGAA course, traced the arc of this technology from the earliest chemical methods through the development of solid-phase phosphoramidite chemistry—still the workhorse method used today—to the silicon-chip platforms her company pioneered. She emphasized that the democratization of DNA synthesis has opened the door to applications that would have been unimaginable just twenty years ago: synthetic gene libraries for directed evolution, DNA-encoded chemical libraries for drug discovery, massively parallel CRISPR screens, DNA data storage systems, and the construction of minimal and designer genomes.

Understanding how DNA synthesis works—the chemistry, the engineering, the economics, and the error landscape—is essential for anyone who wants to participate in the synthetic biology revolution. In this module, we will walk through the complete journey from the first dinucleotide to million-oligo chips, from single columns to silicon wafers, and from short oligonucleotides to entire genomes assembled from parts. Along the way, we will examine the fundamental chemistry that makes it all possible, the clever engineering that scaled it up, and the remaining challenges that the next generation of synthesis technologies aims to overcome.

sections.title: Historical Timeline: 1955–Present
sections.content:
The history of DNA synthesis is a story of steady chemical innovation punctuated by dramatic leaps in scale and cost efficiency. Understanding this timeline is important not just for historical appreciation, but because each advance built directly on the last, and the limitations of earlier methods motivated the engineering breakthroughs that followed.

The Pioneering Era (1955–1970)

1955 – Michelson and Todd achieved the first chemical synthesis of a dinucleotide, demonstrating that phosphodiester bonds could be formed in vitro using purely chemical methods. This was a proof-of-concept that organic chemistry could replicate the fundamental linkage of nucleic acids.

1956–1961 – Har Gobind Khorana developed systematic methods for synthesizing defined oligonucleotides in solution. His group used phosphodiester and phosphotriester approaches to construct every possible trinucleotide codon, enabling the complete deciphering of the genetic code. Khorana's group also achieved the first complete synthesis of a gene—the 77-nucleotide yeast alanine tRNA gene—in 1972, a tour de force that took years of painstaking work.

1965 – Robert Letsinger introduced a critical innovation: solid-phase synthesis. Rather than performing reactions in solution (where purification between steps was laborious), Letsinger attached the growing oligonucleotide chain to an insoluble polymer bead. This allowed reagents and byproducts to be simply washed away, dramatically simplifying the workflow and paving the way for automation. Letsinger also pioneered the use of phosphite triester intermediates, which were more reactive than the phosphodiester and phosphotriester methods used previously.

The Phosphoramidite Revolution (1981–1990)

1981 – Marvin Caruthers developed phosphoramidite chemistry, which combined Letsinger's solid-phase approach with highly reactive phosphoramidite monomers. This method offered coupling efficiencies exceeding 99% and cycle times of just a few minutes per nucleotide. Caruthers' chemistry became—and remains today—the standard method for DNA synthesis worldwide. It enabled the first commercial DNA synthesizers, which appeared in the early 1980s from Applied Biosystems and other manufacturers.

1983–1985 – The arrival of automated DNA synthesizers made custom oligonucleotides accessible to ordinary molecular biology laboratories for the first time. Researchers could order or synthesize primers for PCR (itself invented by Kary Mullis in 1983), probes for hybridization, and linkers for cloning. The cost per base was still high—on the order of $10–$50 per base—but the convenience was transformative.

Gene Synthesis and Cost Collapse (1990–2010)

Through the 1990s, improvements in phosphoramidite chemistry, solid supports, and automated instrumentation gradually reduced costs and improved quality. The idea of gene synthesis—assembling short oligos into complete genes of 1–10 kb—became practical.

2003 – Hamilton Smith and colleagues at the J. Craig Venter Institute synthesized the complete 5,386-nucleotide genome of bacteriophage phiX174 from synthetic oligonucleotides in just two weeks, demonstrating that entire viral genomes could be built from scratch.

2010 – The Venter Institute achieved a landmark: the synthesis and assembly of the complete 1.08 million base pair genome of Mycoplasma mycoides JCVI-syn1.0, which was transplanted into a recipient cell to create what was dubbed the first "synthetic cell." The genome was assembled hierarchically from 1,078 overlapping oligonucleotides, through intermediate cassettes in yeast, to the full chromosome.

The Chip-Based Era (2010–Present)

The most dramatic recent development has been the shift from column-based synthesis (one oligo per column) to chip-based massively parallel synthesis.

2012–2015 – Twist Bioscience, Agilent, CustomArray, and others developed platforms that synthesize hundreds of thousands to millions of distinct oligonucleotides on silicon chips or microarrays. This reduced the effective cost per oligo by roughly 1,000-fold.

Today, a gene of 1–2 kb can be synthesized for under $0.05–$0.10 per base pair, and oligo pool costs can be as low as $0.001 per base or less when amortized across millions of sequences on a chip. The overall cost trajectory has followed an exponential decline:

YearApprox. Cost per BaseTechnology
1970s$500–$1,000Solution-phase (Khorana methods)
1985$10–$50Early automated phosphoramidite
2000$0.50–$2.00Mature column-based synthesis
2010$0.10–$0.50Gene synthesis companies
2020+$0.02–$0.07Chip-based synthesis (Twist, etc.)

This cost curve has profound implications. When writing DNA was expensive, experiments were designed conservatively—you might order one or two gene variants. Today, you can affordably order entire libraries of thousands of variants simultaneously, enabling combinatorial approaches to protein engineering, metabolic pathway optimization, and functional genomics that were previously inconceivable.

sections.title: Phosphoramidite Chemistry: The Four-Step Cycle
sections.content:
Phosphoramidite chemistry is the engine that drives virtually all chemical DNA synthesis performed today. Developed by Marvin Caruthers in 1981 and refined continuously since, it is a marvel of synthetic organic chemistry—a precisely choreographed four-step cycle that adds one nucleotide at a time to a growing oligonucleotide chain anchored to a solid support. Understanding this cycle in detail is essential for appreciating both the power and the limitations of modern DNA synthesis.

The Solid Support

Synthesis begins with the solid support, typically controlled pore glass (CPG) beads or polystyrene (PS) beads, packed into a small column or deposited in a well on a microchip. The first nucleoside—corresponding to the 3′ end of the desired oligonucleotide—is pre-attached to the support via a cleavable linker (usually a succinate ester). All subsequent chemistry takes place while the growing chain remains tethered to this support, a key innovation because it allows reagents, solvents, and byproducts to be simply washed away between steps without the need for chromatographic purification.

An important and initially counterintuitive feature: DNA synthesis by phosphoramidite chemistry proceeds in the 3′ → 5′ direction, which is the opposite of the 5′ → 3′ direction used by DNA polymerases in biological replication. This is because the chemistry requires the incoming nucleotide to be activated at its 3′-phosphoramidite group and to react with the free 5′-hydroxyl of the support-bound chain.

Step 1: Deprotection (Detritylation)

Each nucleotide on the growing chain bears a dimethoxytrityl (DMT) protecting group on its 5′-hydroxyl. This large, hydrophobic group prevents unwanted reactions at that position during the coupling step. Before a new nucleotide can be added, the DMT group must be removed.

Deprotection is accomplished by briefly exposing the support-bound chain to a solution of trichloroacetic acid (TCA), typically 2–3% in dichloromethane. The acid-labile DMT group is cleaved within seconds, releasing a bright orange-colored DMT cation into the wash solution. This color is not merely cosmetic—it provides a convenient, real-time readout of deprotection efficiency. By measuring the absorbance of the orange effluent (the DMT cation absorbs strongly at 498 nm), the synthesizer can monitor the trityl yield at each cycle, providing an ongoing check on synthesis quality.

The free 5′-hydroxyl left behind after detritylation is now the reactive nucleophile that will attack the incoming phosphoramidite in the next step.

Step 2: Coupling

The coupling step is the heart of the synthesis cycle and the one that most critically determines overall yield and quality. The next nucleoside phosphoramidite monomer—dissolved in anhydrous acetonitrile—is delivered to the column along with an activator, most commonly tetrazole or one of its derivatives (such as 5-ethylthio-1H-tetrazole, ETT, or 5-benzylthio-1H-tetrazole, BTT).

The activator protonates the diisopropylamino group on the phosphoramidite, converting it into a highly electrophilic phosphorus center. The free 5′-hydroxyl of the support-bound chain then attacks this activated phosphorus in a nucleophilic substitution reaction, forming a new phosphite triester linkage. This reaction is extremely fast—typically complete within 20–30 seconds for standard DNA phosphoramidites—but it must be performed under strictly anhydrous (water-free) conditions, because even trace moisture will hydrolyze the phosphoramidite and destroy it before coupling can occur.

The coupling efficiency—the fraction of support-bound chains that successfully add the next nucleotide—is the single most important parameter in oligonucleotide synthesis. Modern phosphoramidite chemistry routinely achieves coupling efficiencies of 98.5–99.5% per step. This sounds impressively high, but the compounding effect of even small inefficiencies becomes dramatic for longer oligonucleotides. The overall yield of full-length product follows the formula:

Full-length yield = (coupling efficiency)N

where N is the number of coupling steps (equal to the oligo length minus one). Consider a 200-nucleotide oligonucleotide (200-mer) synthesized at 99% coupling efficiency:

0.99199 = 0.134, or about 13.4% full-length product

At 99.5% efficiency, the same 200-mer gives 0.995199 = 0.369, or about 37% full-length. And at 98% efficiency, the yield drops to a dismal 0.98199 = 0.018, or under 2%. This exponential decay is the fundamental reason why chemical synthesis is practically limited to oligonucleotides of about 150–300 nucleotides, depending on the coupling efficiency of the particular instrument and chemistry being used. Longer constructs must be assembled from multiple shorter oligos.

Step 3: Capping

Despite best efforts, some fraction of the support-bound chains—typically 0.5–1.5%—will fail to couple at each step, retaining their free 5′-hydroxyl. If left unreacted, these failure sequences would participate in subsequent coupling cycles, producing oligonucleotides with internal deletions (missing one or more bases). Such deletion products are the most problematic type of synthesis error because they are nearly the same length as the full-length product and difficult to separate by standard purification methods.

To prevent this, the capping step acetylates any remaining free 5′-hydroxyls, using a mixture of acetic anhydride and N-methylimidazole (or DMAP as a catalyst) in THF. The resulting acetyl cap permanently blocks these failure chains from further extension, effectively terminating them. This ensures that the only chains that continue growing are those that successfully coupled at every step.

The capped failure sequences remain attached to the support throughout the synthesis but are ultimately washed away or separated during post-synthesis purification. While capping reduces the total amount of full-length product, it dramatically improves the purity of that product by eliminating the most insidious class of errors.

Step 4: Oxidation

The coupling step produces a phosphite triester (PIII) linkage between the two nucleotides. This intermediate is relatively unstable and must be converted to the much more stable phosphate triester (PV) that is found in native DNA. Oxidation is performed using a solution of iodine in water/pyridine/THF (often called the "oxidizer"), which converts PIII to PV in a matter of seconds.

In some protocols, particularly for synthesizing phosphorothioate oligonucleotides (used as antisense therapeutics), this oxidation step is replaced with a sulfurization step using a sulfur-transfer reagent like Beaucage reagent or DDTT. This introduces a sulfur atom in place of one of the non-bridging oxygens, conferring nuclease resistance to the final oligonucleotide.

Try it: Calculate the full-length yield for a 100-mer oligo at three different coupling efficiencies: 98%, 99%, and 99.5%. Then calculate how many clones you would need to screen to find at least one perfect sequence if the error rate is 1 in 150 bases. Which coupling efficiency would you need to make a 300-mer practical?

Hint: Use the formula yield = (efficiency)^(N-1). For 100-mer: 0.98^99 = 13.4%, 0.99^99 = 37%, 0.995^99 = 61%. For finding a perfect clone from a 100-mer with 1/150 error rate, the probability of a perfect oligo is (149/150)^100 = ~51%, so you would need to screen only ~2 clones on average. For 300-mer, even 99.5% gives only 22% full-length product.

Deep dive: The requirement for strictly anhydrous conditions during coupling is one of the most critical operational constraints in DNA synthesis. Water molecules compete with the 5′-hydroxyl for reaction with the activated phosphoramidite, and even 10 ppm of water in the acetonitrile solvent can measurably reduce coupling efficiency. This is why synthesis-grade acetonitrile has a maximum water specification of 10 ppm or less, and why the synthesis lines are purged with dry argon. On chip-based platforms like Twist's silicon chips, controlling moisture is even more challenging because of the open architecture and the need to deliver reagents to millions of tiny wells simultaneously. The engineering solutions—including hermetic sealing, controlled atmosphere chambers, and precisely timed reagent delivery—are what make high-fidelity chip synthesis possible.

Cycle Time and Throughput

A complete deprotection–coupling–capping–oxidation cycle takes approximately 5–8 minutes on modern automated synthesizers. A 20-mer oligo (a typical PCR primer) can therefore be synthesized in about 2 hours. A 100-mer takes roughly 8–10 hours. Longer oligos of 150–200 nucleotides may require overnight runs, and the post-synthesis processing—cleavage from the support, deprotection of the base-protecting groups, and purification—adds additional time.

Error Rates in Chemical vs. Biological Synthesis

Chemical DNA synthesis achieves an error rate of approximately 1 in 100 to 1 in 200 bases (roughly 1:102). The dominant error types are single-base deletions (from incomplete coupling), insertions (from incomplete capping or DMT removal), and point substitutions (from depurination or other side reactions during the acid deprotection step).

For comparison, the DNA polymerase III holoenzyme in E. coli achieves an error rate of approximately 1 in 1,000,000 bases (1:106) thanks to the combined fidelity of its active site, 3′→5′ proofreading exonuclease, and post-replication mismatch repair. This four-orders-of-magnitude gap between chemical and biological fidelity is one of the central challenges of DNA synthesis and motivates the error correction strategies discussed later in this module.

Post-Synthesis Processing

After synthesis is complete, the oligonucleotide must be cleaved from the solid support and fully deprotected. Cleavage is typically performed with concentrated ammonium hydroxide at elevated temperature (55–65 °C), which simultaneously removes the base-protecting groups (benzoyl on A and C, isobutyryl or dimethylformamidine on G). The crude oligonucleotide is then purified—most commonly by reversed-phase HPLC (using the DMT group as a hydrophobic handle for "trityl-on" purification), PAGE (polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis) for length-based separation, or ion-exchange chromatography. For many routine applications like PCR primers, simple desalting by size-exclusion chromatography is sufficient.

checkQuestion.question: If a 200-nucleotide oligo is synthesized at 99% coupling efficiency per step, approximately what percentage of the final product will be full-length?
checkQuestion.explanation: The full-length yield follows the formula (coupling efficiency)^N. At 99% efficiency over 199 coupling steps: 0.99^199 = approximately 0.134, or about 13% full-length product. This exponential decay is why chemical synthesis is practically limited to ~150–300 nucleotides.

sections.title: Column vs. Chip-Based Synthesis
sections.content:
The phosphoramidite chemistry cycle is the same regardless of format, but the physical platform on which that chemistry is performed has enormous implications for throughput, cost, and applications. The two major formats—traditional column-based synthesis and modern chip-based (array-based) synthesis—serve complementary needs, and understanding their differences is critical for designing experiments and choosing the right vendor.

Column-Based Synthesis: One Sequence at a Time

In traditional column-based synthesis, the solid support (CPG or polystyrene beads) is packed into a small plastic or glass column, typically holding 40 nanomoles to 1 micromole of starting material. Reagents are pumped through the column in sequence, and the four-step cycle is performed for each nucleotide addition. Each column produces a single oligonucleotide sequence.

The key strengths of column synthesis are quantity and quality. A standard 1-µmol synthesis yields enough oligo for thousands of PCR reactions or dozens of cloning experiments. Coupling efficiencies tend to be high because the chemistry is well-controlled in the column format, and purification options (HPLC, PAGE) are well-established. Column synthesis remains the method of choice for applications requiring large quantities of a single sequence: PCR primers, sequencing adapters, synthetic genes (assembled from column-synthesized oligos), and therapeutic oligonucleotides such as antisense drugs and siRNAs.

The major limitation is throughput. A single 96-column synthesizer running in parallel produces 96 distinct oligos per run. Even large oligo synthesis facilities running dozens of such instruments can produce only thousands of unique sequences per day. When an experiment requires tens of thousands or millions of distinct sequences—as in CRISPR guide RNA libraries, variant libraries for directed evolution, or DNA-encoded chemical libraries—column synthesis is simply not scalable.

Chip-Based Synthesis: Millions of Sequences at Once

Chip-based (or array-based) synthesis addresses the throughput bottleneck by performing the phosphoramidite chemistry in a massively parallel format on a silicon wafer or glass microarray. Instead of one column, imagine hundreds of thousands to over one million tiny synthesis sites ("features" or "spots") on a single chip, each producing a different oligonucleotide sequence.

Twist Bioscience uses a proprietary silicon platform where each synthesis site is a miniaturized well etched into a silicon wafer, with chemistry controlled by microfluidic delivery of reagents to specific wells. Their current platform synthesizes up to 1 million oligos per chip, with each oligo typically 150–300 nucleotides in length. The amount of each oligo produced is small—femtomoles rather than nanomoles—but when the application is gene assembly or library construction, only small amounts of each oligo are needed.

Agilent Technologies uses a different approach based on inkjet printing: phosphoramidite reagents are delivered to specific spots on a glass slide by inkjet printheads, similar to how an inkjet printer deposits ink on paper. This allows precise spatial control of which nucleotide is coupled at each position.

Photodeprotection methods, pioneered by Affymetrix for DNA microarrays and further developed by others, use light instead of acid to remove protecting groups. In this approach, nucleotides bear photolabile protecting groups (such as NPPOC or MeNPOC) on their 5′-hydroxyls. A digital micromirror device (DMD) or photolithographic mask directs UV light to specific spots on the array, selectively deprotecting only those positions where the next nucleotide should be coupled. This enables synthesis of hundreds of thousands of distinct sequences using the same four phosphoramidite monomers, differentiated only by the spatial pattern of light exposure at each cycle.

CustomArray (now part of GenScript) developed an electrochemical approach where deprotection is triggered by locally generated acid from an electrode at each synthesis site, providing yet another mechanism for spatial control.

Cost Implications

The economics of chip-based synthesis are transformative. Because the cost of the chip, reagents, and instrument time is shared across all the sequences on the chip, the per-oligo cost drops by approximately 1,000-fold compared to column synthesis. A column-synthesized 200-mer might cost $50–$200 individually; the same sequence as part of a Twist oligo pool costs a fraction of a cent.

However, there is a tradeoff. Each individual oligo is produced in very small quantities—typically femtomoles, enough for PCR amplification and cloning but not for direct use in applications requiring micrograms of material. Additionally, chip-synthesized oligo pools are complex mixtures; extracting a single sequence from a million-oligo pool requires additional steps such as selective PCR amplification ("dial-out") or barcoded retrieval.

Choosing the Right Platform

FeatureColumn SynthesisChip-Based Synthesis
Sequences per run1–9610,000–1,000,000+
Quantity per oligoNanomoles to micromolesFemtomoles
Typical lengthUp to ~200 ntUp to ~300 nt
Cost per oligo$10–$200$0.001–$0.01
Best forPrimers, probes, individual genesLibraries, gene assembly pools, screens
PurificationHPLC, PAGE, desaltTypically PCR amplification from pool

For the HTGAA course homework, where you will order synthetic DNA from Twist Bioscience, you are leveraging the chip-based platform. The sequences you design will be synthesized alongside thousands of other customers' sequences on the same silicon chip, which is why the turnaround time and minimum order requirements differ from traditional column oligo orders.

options: 1 million

checkQuestion.explanation: Twist Bioscience's silicon platform synthesizes up to approximately 1 million distinct oligonucleotides per chip, each in a miniaturized well. This massive parallelization reduces the per-oligo cost by roughly 1,000-fold compared to column-based synthesis.

sections.title: From Oligos to Genes: Assembly Methods
sections.content:
Chemical DNA synthesis, whether column-based or chip-based, is practically limited to oligonucleotides of about 150–300 nucleotides. But the genes, pathways, and genomes that synthetic biologists want to construct range from a few hundred bases to over a million. Bridging this gap requires assembly methods that join short synthetic oligos into progressively longer constructs. Several powerful assembly strategies have been developed, each with distinct advantages, and they can be used hierarchically to build DNA constructs of virtually any size.

Gibson Assembly

Gibson Assembly, developed by Daniel Gibson at the J. Craig Venter Institute in 2009, is arguably the most widely used method for joining multiple DNA fragments. Its elegance lies in its simplicity: all you need are DNA fragments with overlapping ends (typically 20–40 bp of shared sequence between adjacent fragments) and a single master mix containing three enzymes, incubated at 50 °C for 15–60 minutes in a single tube.

The three enzymes and their roles are:

  1. T5 exonuclease: This 5′→3′ exonuclease chews back the 5′ ends of double-stranded DNA fragments, creating long 3′ single-stranded overhangs. Where two fragments share overlapping sequence, the exposed complementary 3′ overhangs anneal to each other, joining the fragments in the correct order. The T5 exonuclease is heat-labile and is gradually inactivated at 50 °C during the reaction, which is an important design feature—it prevents excessive chewback that would destroy the fragments.
  2. Phusion DNA polymerase: This high-fidelity polymerase fills in any gaps left after the 3′ overhangs have annealed, extending from the 3′ end of each fragment to create a continuous double-stranded molecule.
  3. Taq DNA ligase: This thermostable ligase seals the remaining nicks (single-strand breaks) in the phosphodiester backbone, producing a covalently closed, intact double-stranded DNA product.

Gibson Assembly can join 2–10+ fragments in a single reaction, making it possible to assemble entire genes (1–10 kb) or even small pathways from a collection of overlapping oligos or PCR products. The key design requirement is that each pair of adjacent fragments must share 20–40 bp of identical sequence at their junction, and these overlaps must be unique (no repeated sequences that could cause misassembly).

For the HTGAA homework, Gibson Assembly is a method you should understand well, as it is the standard approach for assembling the synthetic DNA fragments you order from Twist into functional constructs.

Golden Gate Assembly

Golden Gate Assembly takes a different approach, relying on Type IIS restriction enzymes—enzymes that cut outside their recognition sequence, generating custom 4-base overhangs. The most commonly used enzyme is BsaI, which recognizes GGTCTC and cuts 1 bp downstream on the sense strand and 4 bp downstream on the antisense strand, leaving a 4-nucleotide 5′ overhang whose sequence is determined by the DNA, not the enzyme.

By designing each fragment with BsaI sites positioned to generate unique, non-palindromic 4-bp overhangs at each junction, you can direct the ordered assembly of multiple fragments in a single reaction containing BsaI and T4 DNA ligase. The beauty of this system is that the restriction and ligation reactions occur simultaneously in a thermocycling protocol (alternating between 37 °C for cutting and 16 °C for ligation), and the correctly assembled product lacks any BsaI sites (because assembly consumes them), so the reaction is driven to completion.

Golden Gate is particularly powerful for combinatorial assembly using standardized part libraries (as in the MoClo and GoldenBraid systems), where you want to mix and match promoters, coding sequences, terminators, and other genetic parts in all possible combinations. A set of 4-bp overhangs can encode up to 256 (44) distinct junctions, and with careful design, 10–20+ fragments can be assembled with high efficiency and correct directionality.

Behind the scenes: The design of Gibson Assembly overlaps is more nuanced than it first appears. The overlaps must be 20–40 bp, but they also need to have a melting temperature (Tm) of approximately 48–63°C, should not form strong secondary structures (hairpins), and must be unique across all junctions in the assembly. If two different junctions share similar overlap sequences, the T5 exonuclease will expose complementary regions that can mis-anneal, causing chimeric or rearranged products. Software tools like NEBuilder, SnapGene, and Benchling automate overlap design and check for these pitfalls. For assemblies of 5+ fragments, experimental success rates drop to ~50–70%, so many labs perform the assembly, transform into E. coli, and screen 4–8 colonies by sequencing to find a correct one.

Challenge: You want to build a 5-gene metabolic pathway (~12 kb total) from synthetic oligos. The genes come from three different organisms and have varying GC content (35–72%). Design an assembly strategy: how many levels of hierarchy would you use, what assembly method at each level, and what size fragments would you order from Twist?

Hint: A practical approach: order 200-nt oligos from Twist that tile across each gene with 30-bp overlaps. Assemble each gene separately (~2–3 kb) using Gibson Assembly (Level 1). Sequence-verify each gene in a cloning vector. Then do a second Gibson Assembly of all 5 verified genes plus a backbone vector (Level 2). The high-GC gene may need codon optimization to reduce GC content below 65% for reliable synthesis.

Overlap Extension PCR

Overlap extension PCR (OE-PCR) is a simpler but less scalable method for joining DNA fragments. Fragments are designed with overlapping ends (similar to Gibson Assembly), then mixed and subjected to PCR. During the initial cycles without flanking primers, the overlapping ends of adjacent fragments anneal and are extended by the polymerase, creating fused products. Flanking primers are then added to amplify the full-length assembled product.

OE-PCR works well for joining 2–4 fragments and is widely used for site-directed mutagenesis (introducing point mutations by designing overlapping primers that span the mutation site). However, it is less efficient for larger assemblies because the probability of correct assembly decreases as the number of fragments increases, and PCR can introduce additional errors.

Hierarchical Assembly: Building Genomes

For constructs larger than ~10 kb, a hierarchical assembly strategy is typically employed. Short oligos (150–300 nt) are first assembled into intermediate fragments of 1–5 kb using Gibson or Golden Gate assembly. These intermediates are then cloned into vectors, sequence-verified, and assembled into larger cassettes of 10–50 kb. The cassettes are further combined into megachunks and ultimately into complete chromosomes.

This was exactly the strategy used by the Venter Institute to build the Mycoplasma mycoides synthetic genome:

  1. Level 1: 1,078 overlapping 1-kb oligonucleotides were chemically synthesized
  2. Level 2: Sets of 10 oligos were assembled into ~10-kb cassettes in E. coli
  3. Level 3: Sets of 10 cassettes were assembled into ~100-kb segments in S. cerevisiae (yeast)
  4. Level 4: 11 segments were assembled into the complete 1.08-Mb genome in yeast

Yeast was used for the larger assemblies because its homologous recombination machinery is exceptionally efficient at joining overlapping DNA fragments in vivo, even fragments as large as 100 kb. This biological assembly step neatly complements the chemical synthesis and in vitro assembly steps at earlier levels.

Whole Genome Synthesis Milestones

The milestones in whole genome synthesis illustrate the rapid progress in this field:

  • 2002: Cello, Paul, and Wimmer synthesized the 7.5-kb poliovirus genome from mail-ordered oligos
  • 2003: Smith, Hutchison, and Venter synthesized the 5.4-kb phiX174 bacteriophage genome in 2 weeks
  • 2008: The Venter Institute assembled the 583-kb M. genitalium genome (though it was not successfully booted)
  • 2010: The 1.08-Mb M. mycoides JCVI-syn1.0 genome was synthesized, assembled, and successfully transplanted
  • 2016: JCVI-syn3.0, a minimal genome of 531 kb (473 genes), was designed and synthesized
  • 2019–2021: The Sc2.0 project began delivering synthetic S. cerevisiae chromosomes, working toward a fully synthetic eukaryotic genome of ~12 Mb

Each of these milestones pushed the boundaries of what could be assembled from synthetic parts, demonstrating that biology at the genome scale is increasingly an engineering discipline.

checkQuestion.question: In Gibson Assembly, what is the role of the T5 exonuclease?
options: It seals nicks in the DNA backbone
It fills gaps after fragment annealing
It chews back 5′ ends to create 3′ single-stranded overhangs for annealing
It adds a poly-A tail to each fragment
checkQuestion.explanation: T5 exonuclease is a 5′→3′ exonuclease that degrades the 5′ ends of double-stranded fragments, exposing complementary 3′ single-stranded overhangs that anneal where fragments share overlapping sequence. It is heat-labile and gradually inactivates at 50°C to prevent over-digestion.

sections.title: Error Correction & Quality Control
sections.content:
The gap between chemical synthesis fidelity (~1 error per 100–200 bases) and biological replication fidelity (~1 error per 1,000,000 bases) is perhaps the most significant technical challenge in DNA synthesis. For a 1-kb gene synthesized from oligos, you can expect roughly 5–10 errors in the raw product. For a 10-kb pathway, that number climbs to 50–100 errors. Clearly, raw synthetic DNA cannot be used directly for most applications without some form of error correction or selection for correct sequences.

Types of Synthesis Errors

Understanding the types of errors that arise during chemical synthesis is essential for devising correction strategies:

  • Deletions (~60% of errors): The most common error type, arising primarily from incomplete coupling. When a nucleotide fails to couple and is not fully capped, or when depurination occurs during the acid deprotection step (leading to strand cleavage and loss of one or more bases). Deletions are particularly problematic because a single-base deletion in a coding sequence causes a frameshift, completely disrupting the encoded protein from that point onward.
  • Insertions (~15% of errors): Arise from incomplete deprotection (a nucleotide retains its DMT group and is not extended, but then loses the DMT in a subsequent cycle and couples out of order) or from branching reactions. Like deletions, insertions cause frameshifts.
  • Substitutions (~25% of errors): Arise from depurination (loss of a purine base under acidic conditions, particularly for adenine), oxidative damage, or contamination of phosphoramidite reagents. Substitutions are less catastrophic than frameshifts—they produce point mutations—but can still inactivate a gene if they occur at critical positions.

MutS Mismatch Binding

One of the most elegant error correction strategies exploits the bacterial MutS protein, a key component of the DNA mismatch repair system. MutS binds specifically to DNA duplexes containing mismatches (base-base mismatches, small insertions, and small deletions). In the error correction protocol:

  1. Synthetic oligonucleotides are denatured and reannealed, so that strands from different oligo molecules hybridize. If two strands both have an error at the same position (unlikely, since errors are random), they will form a correct base pair; but most errors will create mismatches in the heteroduplex.
  2. MutS protein (or its thermostable homolog, such as Thermus aquaticus MutS) is added, binding specifically to the mismatched duplexes.
  3. The MutS-bound error-containing duplexes are removed—either by column chromatography (the MutS is tagged or immobilized), gel shift, or other separation methods—leaving behind the error-free duplexes.

MutS-based error correction can reduce the error rate by approximately 10–15-fold, from roughly 1 in 200 bases to 1 in 2,000–3,000 bases. Some commercial gene synthesis providers (including Twist) incorporate MutS or similar mismatch-binding steps into their standard workflows.

Dial-Out PCR

An alternative approach to error correction is dial-out PCR, which exploits the fact that chip-synthesized oligo pools contain many independent copies of each intended sequence, and these copies have random, uncorrelated errors. The strategy is:

  1. Each oligo in the pool is designed with a unique barcode (typically appended to one or both ends).
  2. The pool is amplified and cloned, then individual clones are sequenced (e.g., by next-generation sequencing).
  3. Clones containing the correct sequence are identified by their barcodes and selectively retrieved by barcode-specific PCR ("dialing out" individual correct sequences from the library).

This approach is particularly powerful for chip-synthesized oligo pools, where each intended sequence is represented by many independent molecules. Since errors are random, the probability that at least one copy of a given sequence is error-free increases with the number of independent molecules, and dial-out PCR allows you to find and retrieve those correct copies.

Next-Generation Sequencing Verification

Regardless of the error correction method used, the final step in any gene synthesis workflow is sequence verification. Before using a synthetic gene or construct in an experiment, it must be sequenced to confirm that it matches the intended design. Historically, this was done by Sanger sequencing—the gold standard for verifying short constructs up to ~800 bp. For longer constructs, multiple Sanger reads are needed, using primers spaced along the construct.

Increasingly, next-generation sequencing (NGS) is being used for verification, particularly for large numbers of clones or for complex libraries. Oxford Nanopore sequencing is especially attractive for this purpose because it can sequence entire plasmids or multi-kilobase constructs in a single read, without the need for primer walking. Services like Plasmidsaurus offer full-plasmid nanopore sequencing for a few dollars per sample, making comprehensive verification increasingly routine.

Comparing Error Rates Across Methods

MethodTypical Error RateNotes
Raw column synthesis~1 in 100–200 bpDominated by deletions
Raw chip synthesis~1 in 100–300 bpVariable by platform and oligo position on chip
After MutS correction~1 in 2,000–3,000 bp10–15x improvement
After clonal selection + sequencingEffectively 0 (verified)Requires sequencing each clone
Biological replication (E. coli)~1 in 106–109 bpProofreading + mismatch repair

The practical takeaway is that for any application requiring correct sequences—which is nearly all applications—you should always sequence-verify your synthetic DNA before using it. Error correction methods like MutS and dial-out PCR reduce the number of clones you need to screen to find a correct one, saving time and money, but they do not eliminate the need for verification.

checkQuestion.question: What is the most common type of error in chemically synthesized DNA?
options: Substitutions (point mutations)
Translocations (rearrangements)
Deletions (missing bases)
Insertions (extra bases)
checkQuestion.explanation: Deletions account for approximately 60% of chemical synthesis errors, arising primarily from incomplete coupling reactions. They are especially problematic because a single-base deletion in a coding sequence causes a frameshift that disrupts the entire downstream protein.

sections.title: Emerging Methods & DNA Data Storage
sections.content:
While phosphoramidite chemistry has served the field remarkably well for over four decades, its fundamental limitations—organic solvents, anhydrous conditions, length ceilings, and intrinsic error rates—have motivated the development of entirely new synthesis paradigms. At the same time, the ability to write DNA has opened up an application that would have seemed like science fiction just a few decades ago: using DNA as a medium for digital data storage.

Enzymatic DNA Synthesis with TdT

The most promising alternative to phosphoramidite chemistry is enzymatic DNA synthesis using terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT). TdT is a naturally occurring template-independent DNA polymerase that adds nucleotides to the 3′ end of single-stranded DNA without requiring a template strand. In the enzymatic synthesis approach:

  1. A modified nucleotide bearing a reversible 3′-blocking group (conceptually similar to the reversible terminators used in Illumina sequencing) is presented to TdT.
  2. TdT adds the nucleotide to the 3′ end of the growing chain.
  3. The 3′-blocking group prevents further extension, ensuring that exactly one nucleotide is added per cycle.
  4. The blocking group is chemically or enzymatically removed, and the cycle repeats.

DNA Script (now part of a merged entity) has been the leading commercial developer of TdT-based enzymatic synthesis, with their SYNTAX system. The key advantages over phosphoramidite chemistry include:

  • Aqueous conditions: The entire process occurs in water-based buffers, eliminating the need for toxic organic solvents like acetonitrile and dichloromethane.
  • Milder chemistry: No strong acids or harsh oxidizing agents are needed.
  • Potential for longer oligos: Because the enzyme is more selective than chemical coupling, there is potential for higher per-step fidelity and longer achievable lengths, though this is still being optimized.
  • Benchtop instruments: Enzymatic synthesis may enable desktop DNA printers that can be operated in a standard molecular biology laboratory without specialized ventilation or waste handling.

As of the mid-2020s, enzymatic synthesis is still maturing. Coupling efficiencies and achievable lengths have been improving rapidly but have not yet fully matched the best phosphoramidite results for all applications. The technology is complementary: phosphoramidite chemistry excels at established high-throughput production, while enzymatic synthesis offers a pathway toward greener, more accessible, and potentially higher-fidelity synthesis in the future.

DNA Data Storage

One of the most visionary applications of DNA synthesis is DNA data storage—encoding arbitrary digital information (text, images, video, software) into synthetic DNA sequences. The motivation is extraordinary: DNA is the densest information storage medium known, with a theoretical capacity of approximately 1018 bytes (1 exabyte) per gram. For context, that means all the data ever created by humanity could theoretically be stored in a few kilograms of DNA.

Beyond density, DNA offers several other compelling properties as a storage medium:

  • Stability: Under appropriate conditions (cool, dark, dry), DNA can remain intact for thousands to hundreds of thousands of years. Ancient DNA from woolly mammoths and Neanderthals has been successfully sequenced after tens of thousands of years of preservation.
  • No power required: Unlike hard drives, flash memory, or tape, DNA requires no electricity to maintain its information content.
  • Universal readout: As long as sequencing technology exists (and there is no reason to think it will disappear), DNA can always be read. There are no format obsolescence concerns.

The pioneering demonstration of DNA data storage was George Church's 2012 experiment, in which his group encoded an entire 53,000-word book (including images and a JavaScript program) into DNA. The encoding scheme mapped binary data to DNA bases, the sequences were synthesized, and the data was recovered by sequencing and decoding.

Since then, the field has advanced rapidly. Microsoft Research and the University of Washington have demonstrated systems that can store and retrieve hundreds of megabytes in DNA. Random access has been achieved using PCR primers that target specific files within a DNA pool. Error-correcting codes (analogous to those used in digital communications) ensure data integrity even in the presence of synthesis and sequencing errors.

The current bottleneck for DNA data storage is cost: writing (synthesis) is far more expensive than electronic storage on a per-bit basis. However, for archival storage—data that must be preserved for decades or centuries but is rarely accessed—the total cost of ownership for DNA storage may become competitive as synthesis costs continue to fall, because there are no ongoing electricity or migration costs.

Cell-Free Synthesis Systems

Another emerging frontier is the use of cell-free transcription-translation (TX-TL) systems as a rapid prototyping platform for synthetic DNA constructs. In a cell-free system, the molecular machinery for gene expression (ribosomes, RNA polymerase, tRNAs, amino acids, energy sources) is extracted from cells and provided in a test tube. Synthetic DNA can be added directly to this system, and protein expression can be observed within hours, without the delays of cloning, transformation, and cell growth.

Cell-free systems are increasingly used in conjunction with DNA synthesis to create rapid design-build-test cycles. A researcher can design a gene variant, order it from Twist, and test its expression in a cell-free system—all within days. This accelerates the engineering cycle dramatically compared to traditional in vivo approaches, which might take weeks for a single design-build-test iteration.

Together, these emerging technologies—enzymatic synthesis, DNA data storage, and cell-free prototyping—point toward a future where DNA writing becomes faster, cheaper, more accurate, and more accessible than ever, enabling applications that extend far beyond traditional molecular biology.

This extraordinary density means that all the data ever generated by humanity could theoretically fit in a few kilograms of DNA.

keyFacts.label: First Chemical Dinucleotide
keyFacts.value: Synthesized by Michelson and Todd in 1955, proving phosphodiester bonds could be formed in vitro

keyFacts.label: Phosphoramidite Chemistry
keyFacts.value: Developed by Marvin Caruthers in 1981, still the standard method used for virtually all commercial DNA synthesis

keyFacts.label: Cycle Time
keyFacts.value: One nucleotide addition takes approximately 5–8 minutes through the four-step deprotection–coupling–capping–oxidation cycle

keyFacts.label: Chemical vs. Biological Error Rate
keyFacts.value: Chemical synthesis: ~1 error per 100–200 bases (1:10²). Biological replication: ~1 error per 1,000,000 bases (1:10⁶)

keyFacts.label: Yield Formula
keyFacts.value: Full-length yield = (coupling efficiency)^N. At 99% over a 200-mer, only ~13% of products are full-length

keyFacts.label: Chip-Based Throughput
keyFacts.value: Twist Bioscience synthesizes ~1 million distinct oligos per silicon chip, reducing per-oligo cost by ~1,000x

keyFacts.label: Largest Synthetic Genome
keyFacts.value: Mycoplasma mycoides JCVI-syn1.0: 1.08 million base pairs, synthesized and assembled by the Venter Institute in 2010

keyFacts.label: DNA Data Density
keyFacts.value: Approximately 10^18 bytes (1 exabyte) per gram—the densest information storage medium known

keyFacts.label: Gibson Assembly
keyFacts.value: Three enzymes (T5 exonuclease, Phusion polymerase, Taq ligase) join overlapping fragments at 50°C in one tube

keyFacts.label: Cost Decline
keyFacts.value: DNA synthesis costs have fallen from ~$1,000/base in the 1970s to under $0.07/base today

vocabulary.definition: The standard chemical method for DNA synthesis, using nucleoside phosphoramidite monomers with protecting groups. Each addition involves a four-step cycle: deprotection, coupling, capping, and oxidation. Developed by Marvin Caruthers in 1981.

A large, acid-labile protecting group on the 5′-hydroxyl of each phosphoramidite monomer. Removed by trichloroacetic acid (TCA) during the deprotection step, releasing an orange-colored cation used to monitor synthesis efficiency.

The percentage of growing chains that successfully add the next nucleotide in each synthesis cycle. Typically 98.5–99.5%. Overall full-length yield equals (coupling efficiency)^N, where N is the number of steps.

A method where the growing oligonucleotide chain is attached to an insoluble support (controlled pore glass or polystyrene beads), allowing reagents and byproducts to be washed away between steps. Pioneered by Robert Letsinger in 1965.

An isothermal method for joining overlapping DNA fragments in a single 50°C reaction using three enzymes: T5 exonuclease (creates overhangs), Phusion polymerase (fills gaps), and Taq ligase (seals nicks). Developed by Daniel Gibson in 2009.
A DNA assembly method using Type IIS restriction enzymes (e.g., BsaI) that cut outside their recognition sites, generating custom 4-base overhangs for ordered, scarless multi-fragment assembly.

A class of restriction enzymes that recognize an asymmetric DNA sequence and cut at a defined distance outside that sequence, generating overhangs with user-defined sequences. BsaI, BbsI, and BsmBI are commonly used in Golden Gate assembly.
A complex mixture of thousands to millions of distinct oligonucleotides synthesized simultaneously on a chip surface. Used for gene assembly, CRISPR libraries, probe sets, and DNA-encoded libraries.

A template-independent DNA polymerase that adds nucleotides to 3′ ends of single-stranded DNA. Being developed as the basis for enzymatic DNA synthesis, which avoids organic solvents and harsh chemicals.

A DNA mismatch repair protein that specifically binds to heteroduplex DNA at mismatch sites. Used in error correction to selectively remove oligos containing synthesis errors from a pool of synthetic DNA.
A method for retrieving specific correct sequences from a complex oligo pool by using unique barcode sequences and barcode-specific PCR primers to selectively amplify individual error-free clones.

A strategy for building large DNA constructs by progressively combining smaller verified fragments into larger ones across multiple levels, from oligos (~200 nt) to cassettes (~10 kb) to segments (~100 kb) to complete chromosomes.
The encoding of arbitrary digital information into synthetic DNA sequences. DNA offers theoretical storage density of ~10^18 bytes/gram and stability over thousands of years without power.

A modified DNA backbone in which one non-bridging oxygen in the phosphodiester bond is replaced by sulfur. This modification confers resistance to nucleases and is used in antisense therapeutic oligonucleotides.

quizQuestions.question: What is the correct order of the four steps in the phosphoramidite synthesis cycle?
options: Coupling, Deprotection, Oxidation, Capping
Deprotection, Coupling, Capping, Oxidation
Oxidation, Coupling, Deprotection, Capping
Capping, Oxidation, Deprotection, Coupling
quizQuestions.explanation: The cycle proceeds: (1) Deprotection removes the 5′-DMT group with TCA, (2) Coupling adds the next phosphoramidite with tetrazole activation, (3) Capping acetylates unreacted hydroxyls, and (4) Oxidation converts the phosphite triester to a phosphate triester with iodine.

quizQuestions.question: Why does chemical DNA synthesis proceed in the 3′ → 5′ direction, opposite to biological replication?
options: Because solid supports can only attach to 3′ ends
Because the chemistry requires the incoming phosphoramidite to react with the free 5′-hydroxyl of the growing chain
Because 5′ → 3′ synthesis would require a template strand
Because phosphoramidite monomers are only available as 3′-modified
quizQuestions.explanation: In phosphoramidite chemistry, the incoming nucleotide is activated at its 3′-phosphoramidite group and reacts with the free 5′-hydroxyl of the support-bound chain, dictating 3′ → 5′ directionality.

quizQuestions.question: What is the purpose of the capping step in phosphoramidite synthesis?
options: To protect the newly formed phosphodiester bond from hydrolysis
To activate the next phosphoramidite monomer for coupling
To permanently block failure sequences from further extension, preventing deletion products
To remove the DMT protecting group from the 5′-hydroxyl
quizQuestions.explanation: Capping acetylates unreacted 5′-hydroxyls on chains that failed to couple, permanently blocking them from participating in subsequent cycles. Without capping, these chains would produce deletion products (oligos missing one or more bases) that are difficult to purify away.

quizQuestions.question: What color is released during the deprotection (detritylation) step, and why is it useful?
options: Blue, because it indicates successful coupling
Orange, because the DMT cation absorbs at 498 nm and allows real-time monitoring of deprotection efficiency
Green, because the phosphoramidite fluoresces upon activation
Red, because the iodine oxidizer changes color upon reduction
quizQuestions.explanation: Removal of the DMT group releases an orange-colored DMT cation that absorbs at 498 nm. Measuring this absorbance in the wash effluent provides a real-time, cycle-by-cycle readout of synthesis efficiency—a valuable quality control metric.

quizQuestions.question: In Gibson Assembly, what prevents the T5 exonuclease from completely degrading the DNA fragments?
options: A specific inhibitor is added after 5 minutes
The exonuclease only digests single-stranded DNA
T5 exonuclease is heat-labile and gradually inactivates at the 50°C reaction temperature
The overlapping sequences block exonuclease activity
quizQuestions.explanation: T5 exonuclease is heat-labile and is gradually inactivated at the 50°C incubation temperature, which is an elegant design feature of Gibson Assembly. This allows initial chewback to expose complementary overhangs but prevents excessive degradation.

quizQuestions.question: What advantage does Golden Gate Assembly have over Gibson Assembly for combinatorial library construction?
options: It uses fewer enzymes and is cheaper
It works at room temperature
Type IIS restriction enzymes create defined 4-bp overhangs enabling ordered, directional multi-part assembly
It does not require any overlapping sequences
quizQuestions.explanation: Golden Gate uses Type IIS enzymes that generate custom 4-bp overhangs, enabling precise ordered assembly of many fragments. The 256 possible 4-bp overhangs allow up to 20+ parts to be assembled directionally, making it ideal for combinatorial approaches with standardized part libraries.

quizQuestions.question: How does the MutS protein help correct errors in synthetic DNA?
options: It repairs mismatches by replacing incorrect bases in situ
It binds specifically to mismatched DNA duplexes, allowing error-containing molecules to be removed from the pool
It degrades single-stranded DNA, leaving only fully double-stranded correct products
It methylates correct sequences so they can be distinguished from incorrect ones
quizQuestions.explanation: MutS binds specifically to DNA duplexes containing mismatches. After synthetic oligos are denatured and reannealed, random errors create mismatches in heteroduplexes. MutS binds these, allowing them to be removed by chromatography or other separation methods, enriching the pool for error-free sequences.

quizQuestions.question: What was the significance of the Venter Institute’s synthesis of the Mycoplasma mycoides genome in 2010?
options: It was the first time a virus was synthesized from scratch
It demonstrated the first complete bacterial genome (1.08 Mb) synthesized from chemical oligos and successfully transplanted into a living cell
It proved that DNA synthesis was cheaper than cloning
It was the first use of phosphoramidite chemistry
quizQuestions.explanation: The 1.08 Mb M. mycoides JCVI-syn1.0 genome was the first complete bacterial genome built from scratch using synthetic oligonucleotides, assembled hierarchically, and transplanted into a recipient cell to create what was called the first 'synthetic cell.'

quizQuestions.question: What key advantage does enzymatic (TdT-based) DNA synthesis offer over phosphoramidite chemistry?
options: It achieves 100% coupling efficiency
It can synthesize oligos over 10,000 bases long
It operates in aqueous conditions without toxic organic solvents
It does not require any protecting groups
quizQuestions.explanation: TdT-based enzymatic synthesis operates entirely in aqueous (water-based) buffers, eliminating the need for toxic organic solvents like acetonitrile and dichloromethane. This makes it potentially safer, greener, and more amenable to benchtop instruments in standard laboratories.

quizQuestions.question: In the context of DNA data storage, what property makes DNA attractive for long-term archival?
options: DNA can be read by the naked eye under UV light
DNA is stable for thousands of years under proper conditions and requires no electricity to maintain
DNA storage is already cheaper per bit than electronic storage
DNA can only store text data, which is ideal for archives
quizQuestions.explanation: DNA can remain intact for thousands to hundreds of thousands of years under cool, dry conditions—far exceeding the lifespan of any electronic medium. It also requires no power to maintain its information, making it ideal for archival storage where longevity matters more than access speed.

quizQuestions.question: What is the primary reason chemical DNA synthesis is limited to about 150–300 nucleotides per oligo?
options: The solid support cannot hold chains longer than 300 nucleotides
Phosphoramidite monomers degrade after 300 cycles
The exponential accumulation of coupling failures means very few full-length products survive beyond ~200–300 nt
Regulatory limits prevent synthesis of sequences longer than 300 bases
quizQuestions.explanation: Even at 99% coupling efficiency, the yield of full-length product decreases exponentially with length: 0.99^199 = 13% for a 200-mer. Beyond ~300 nt, the yield of correct full-length product becomes impractically low for most applications.

quizQuestions.question: Which assembly method was used to build the Mycoplasma mycoides synthetic genome, and what organism's recombination machinery was used for the largest assemblies?
options: Gibson Assembly in E. coli only
Golden Gate Assembly in yeast
Hierarchical assembly using in vitro methods in E. coli and homologous recombination in Saccharomyces cerevisiae (yeast)
Overlap extension PCR performed entirely in vitro
quizQuestions.explanation: The 1.08-Mb genome was built hierarchically: 1,078 oligos were assembled into 10-kb cassettes in E. coli, then into 100-kb segments and the final chromosome in yeast. Yeast was used for the largest assemblies because its homologous recombination machinery efficiently joins large overlapping fragments.

quizQuestions.question: Match each DNA assembly method to its key feature.

pairs.definition: Isothermal one-pot assembly using overlapping fragments
Type IIS restriction enzymes for scarless, directional joining
Chemical addition of one nucleotide per cycle on solid support
PCR-based fusion of fragments using overlapping primers

quizQuestions.explanation: Gibson Assembly uses exonuclease + polymerase + ligase at 50°C. Golden Gate uses Type IIS enzymes (BsaI) that cut outside their recognition site. Phosphoramidite adds bases 3'→5' on CPG beads. OE-PCR fuses fragments via complementary primer tails.

quizQuestions.question: Put the four steps of the phosphoramidite synthesis cycle in the correct order.
items: Detritylation — remove the DMT protecting group with acid
Coupling — add the next phosphoramidite monomer with activator
Oxidation — stabilize the phosphite triester to phosphate
quizQuestions.explanation: The phosphoramidite cycle always follows: Detritylation → Coupling → Capping → Oxidation. This is repeated for each nucleotide addition, building the oligo from 3' to 5'.

conceptConnections.relationship: DNA sequencing (reading) and DNA synthesis (writing) are complementary capabilities. Sequencing is essential for verifying that synthetic DNA matches the intended design, and the same reversible terminator chemistry used in Illumina sequencing inspired the blocking groups used in enzymatic TdT-based synthesis.

CRISPR genome editing makes targeted changes to existing DNA, while DNA synthesis creates entirely new sequences from scratch. Synthesis provides the donor templates, guide RNAs, and engineered Cas proteins used in editing experiments.

The central dogma (DNA → RNA → Protein) defines what synthetic DNA must encode to be functional. Understanding codons, promoters, terminators, and reading frames is essential for designing synthetic genes that will actually express the desired protein.

homeworkConnections.title: Designing Synthetic DNA Sequences
homeworkConnections.relevance: In Part 3 you design a synthetic DNA construct, applying knowledge of codon optimization, assembly junctions, and sequence constraints that arise from the synthesis process. Understanding coupling efficiency and error rates helps you appreciate why sequence design matters.

homeworkConnections.title: Ordering from Twist Bioscience
homeworkConnections.relevance: Part 4 involves placing an actual order with Twist Bioscience, whose chip-based silicon platform is covered in detail in this module. Understanding how Twist’s parallel synthesis works, the length limits (~300 nt per oligo), and the assembly strategies for building longer constructs from these oligos is directly relevant to your order.
